{{featured article}} [[File:Mexico 1835-1846 administrative map-en-2.svg|thumb|upright=1.8|A map of Mexico, 1835–46, showing administrative divisions.|alt=A map of Mexico, 1835–46, showing administrative divisions]] The '''Runaway Scrape''' events took place mainly between September 1835 and April 1836, and were the evacuations by Texas residents fleeing the Mexican Army of Operations during the [[Texas Revolution]], from the [[Battle of the Alamo]] through the decisive [[Battle of San Jacinto]]. The ''[[ad interim]]'' government of the new [[Republic of Texas]] and much of the civilian population fled eastward ahead of the Mexican forces. The conflict arose after [[Antonio López de Santa Anna]] abrogated the 1824 constitution of [[Mexico]] and established [[martial law]] in [[Coahuila y Tejas]]. The [[Texians]]<!--"Texians" is the contemporaneous term, not "Texans"--> resisted and declared their independence. It was [[Sam Houston]]'s responsibility, as the appointed commander-in-chief of the [[Texian Army|Provisional Army of Texas]] (before such an army actually existed), to recruit and train a military force to defend the population against troops led by Santa Anna.
Residents on the Gulf Coast and at [[San Antonio|San Antonio de Béxar]] began evacuating in January upon learning of the Mexican army's troop movements into their area, an event that was ultimately replayed across Texas. During early skirmishes, some Texian soldiers surrendered, believing that they would become [[prisoners of war]] — but Santa Anna demanded their executions. The news of the Battle of the Alamo and the [[Goliad massacre]] instilled fear in the population and resulted in the mass exodus of the civilian population of [[Gonzales, Texas|Gonzales]], where the opening battle of the Texian revolution had begun and where, only days before the fall of the Alamo, they had sent a militia to reinforce the defenders at the mission. The civilian refugees were accompanied by the newly forming provisional army, as Houston bought time to train soldiers and create a military structure that could oppose Santa Anna's greater forces. Houston's actions were viewed as cowardice by the ''ad interim'' government, as well as by some of his own troops. As he and the refugees from Gonzales escaped first to the [[Colorado River (Texas)|Colorado River]] and then to the Brazos, evacuees from other areas trickled in and new militia groups arrived to join with Houston's force.
The towns of Gonzales and [[San Felipe de Austin, Texas|San Felipe de Austin]] were burned to keep them out of the hands of the Mexican army. Santa Anna was intent on executing members of the Republic's interim government, who fled from [[Washington-on-the-Brazos, Texas|Washington-on-the-Brazos]] to Groce's Landing to [[Harrisburg, Houston|Harrisburg]] and [[Morgan's Point, Texas|New Washington]]. The government officials eventually escaped to [[Galveston Island]], and Santa Anna burned the towns of Harrisburg and New Washington when he failed to find them. Approximately 5,000 terrified residents of New Washington fled from the Mexican army. After a little over a month of training the troops, Houston reached a crossroads where he ordered some of them to escort the fleeing refugees farther east while he took the main army southeast to engage the Mexican army. The subsequent Battle of San Jacinto resulted in the surrender of Santa Anna and the signing of the [[Treaties of Velasco]].
==Prelude==
===Changes in Mexico: 1834 - 1835===
In 1834, Mexican president [[Antonio López de Santa Anna]] shifted from a Federalist political ideology to creating a Centralist government and revoked the country's [[1824 Constitution of Mexico|Constitution of 1824]].{{refn|group=FN| name=Federalist|In 19th century Mexico, Federalism was the empowerment of local governments, while Centralism sought to eliminate local political power and give it all to the national government.<ref>Todish ''et al.'' (1998), pp. 2, 4, 6.</ref>}} That constitution had not only established [[Coahuila y Tejas]]{{refn|group=FN| name=Tejas|{{convert|193600|sqmi|km2}}, Mexican provinces of Coahuila and Texas.<ref>Tucker (2012), pp. 151–152.</ref>}} as a new Mexican state, but had also provided for each state in Mexico to create its own local-level constitution.<ref>{{cite web|last1=McKay|first1=S. S.|title=Constitution of Coahuila y Tejas|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/ngc01|website=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}; Haley (2002), p. 116.</ref> After eliminating state-level governments Santa Anna had in effect created a dictatorship and put Coahuila y Tejas under the military rule of General [[Martín Perfecto de Cos]].<ref>Davis (2004), p. 143; Todish ''et al.'' (1998), p. 121.</ref> When Santa Anna made [[Miguel Barragán]] temporary president, he also had Barragán install him as head of the Mexican Army of Operations.<ref>Davis (2004), p. 200.</ref> Intending to put down all rebellion in Coahuila y Tejas, he began amassing his army on November 28, 1835, <ref>Todish ''et al.'' (1998), p. 125.</ref> soon followed by General [[Joaquín Ramírez y Sesma]] leading the Vanguard of the Advance across the [[Rio Grande]] in December.<ref>Todish ''et al.'' (1998), p. 34.</ref>
===Temporary governments in Texas: November 1835 - March 1836===
[[File:Sam Houston Army of Texas recruitment proclamation Dec 12, 1835.jpg|thumb|Sam Houston army recruitment proclamation December 12, 1835|alt=Sam Houston army recruitment proclamation December 12, 1835]]
[[Stephen F. Austin]] was commander of the existing unpaid volunteer [[Texian]] army, and at his urging<ref>Todish ''et al.'' (1998), p. 23.</ref> the [[Consultation (Texas)|Consultation of 1835]] convened in [[San Felipe de Austin, Texas|San Felipe de Austin]] on November 3 of that year. Their creation of a provisional government based on the 1824 constitution<ref>Todish ''et al.'' (1998), p. 24.</ref> established the General Council as a legislative body with each municipality allotted one representative.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Steen|first1=Ralph W.|title=General Council|url=https://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/mbg01|website=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}</ref> [[Henry Smith (Texas governor)|Henry Smith]] was elected governor without any clearly defined powers of the position.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Steen|first1=Ralph W.|title=Henry Smith|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fsm23|website=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}</ref> [[Sam Houston]] was in attendance as the elected representative from [[Nacogdoches, Texas|Nacogdoches]], and also served as commander of the Nacogdoches militia.<ref>Haley (2002), p. 116.</ref> [[Edward Burleson]] replaced Austin as commander of the volunteer army on December 1.
On December 10, the General Council called new elections to choose delegates to determine the fate of the region.<ref>Lack (1992), p. 76.</ref> The Consultation approved the creation of the Provisional Army of Texas, a paid force of 2,500 troops. Houston was named commander-in-chief of the new army and issued a recruitment Proclamation on December 12.{{refn|group=FN| name=Army2|The Provisional Army of Texas consisted of three different categories of enlistees. The Regular Army was much like a modern-day army in its command structure, and had a two-year enlistment period. Permanent Volunteers ran a democratic structure allowing internal elections, and was for the duration of the war. The Volunteer Auxiliary was short-termed with an enlistment period of only six months.<ref>Todish ''et al.'' (1998), pp. 14–15, 24; {{cite web|title=Proclamation of San Houston, A Call for Volunteers, December 12, 1835|url=https://www.tsl.texas.gov/exhibits/texas175/houstonscall.html|website=Texas State Library and Archives Commission|publisher=State of Texas|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}</ref>}}{{refn|group=FN| name=Militia|Locally organized volunteer militias were initially separate from the Provisional Army of Texas and operated autonomously. Whether or not they were paid, or had supplies or uniforms, varied. Each had its own framework and elected leaders. They decided as a unit which battles they would fight. The Consultation only made Houston commander-in-chief of the paid provisional army he was to recruit and train. On March 4, 1836 at Washington-on-the-Brazos, the Convention also put the volunteer militias under Houston's command.<ref>Todish ''et al.'' (1998), pp. 14, 44, 46, 75, 127.</ref>}} The volunteer army under Burleson disbanded on December 20.<ref name="Burleson">{{cite web|last1=Kelso|first1=Helen Burleson|title=Edward Burleson|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fbu40|website=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}</ref>
[[Harrisburg, Texas|Harrisburg]] was designated the seat of a deeply divided provisional government on December 30.<ref name="Harrisburg">{{cite web|last1=Muir|first1=Andrew Forest|title=Harrisburg, Texas (Harris County)|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/hvh27|website=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}</ref> Most of the General Council wanted to remain part of Mexico, but with the restoration of the 1824 constitution. Governor Smith supported the opposing faction who advocated for complete independence. Smith dissolved the General Council on January 10, 1836, but it was unclear if he had the power to do that. He was impeached on January 11. The power struggle effectively shut down the government.<ref name=todish126>Todish ''et al.'' (1998), p.126; {{cite web|last1=Steen|first1=Ralph W.|title=Provisional Government|url=https://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/mzp01|website=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}</ref>
The [[Convention of 1836]] met at [[Washington-on-the-Brazos, Texas|Washington-on-the-Brazos]] on March 1.<ref>Hardin (1994), p. 161.</ref> The following day, the 59 delegates created the [[Republic of Texas]] by affixing their signatures to the [[Texas Declaration of Independence]].<ref>Hardin (1994), p. 161; Lack (1992), p. 83.</ref> Houston's military authority was expanded on March 4, to include "the land forces of the Texian army both Regular, Volunteer, and Militia."<ref>Hatch (1999), p. 188; {{cite web|title=The Texas Revolution: Part C (January–March 7, 1836)|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/lone-star-history-links/1068|website=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 17, 2014}}</ref> The delegates elected the Republic's ''[[ad interim]]'' government on March 16,<ref>{{cite web|title=Ad interim government|url=https://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/mza01|website=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=September 16, 2015}}</ref> with [[David G. Burnet]] as president, [[Lorenzo de Zavala]] as vice president, [[Samuel P. Carson]] as secretary of state, [[Thomas Jefferson Rusk]] as secretary of war, [[Bailey Hardeman]] as secretary of the treasury, [[Robert Potter (U.S. politician)|Robert Potter]] as secretary of the navy, and [[David Thomas (Texas politician)|David Thomas]] as attorney general.<ref>Lack (1992), p. 77.</ref>
==Battle of Gonzales: October 2, 1835== [[File:Gonzales cannon 2005.jpg|thumb|Battle of Gonzales cannon|alt=Battle of Gonzales cannon]] The [[Battle of Gonzales]] was the onset of a chain of events that led to what is known as the Runaway Scrape. The confrontation began in September 1835, when the Mexican government attempted to reclaim a bronze cannon that it had provided to [[Gonzales, Texas|Gonzales]] in 1831 to protect the town against Indian attacks. The first attempt by Corporal Casimiro De León resulted in De León's detachment being taken prisoners, and the cannon being buried in a peach orchard.<ref name="TakeIt"/> [[James C. Neill]], a veteran who had served at the [[Battle of Horseshoe Bend (1814)|Battle of Horseshoe Bend]] under [[Andrew Jackson]], was put in charge of the artillery after it was later dug up and wheel mounted.<ref name="Neill">{{cite web|last1=Hardin|first1=Stephen L.|title=James Clinton Neill|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fne11|website=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}</ref> When Lieutenant [[Francisco de Castañeda]] arrived accompanied by 100 soldiers and made a second attempt at repossessing the cannon, Texians dared the Mexicans to "come and take it".<ref name="TakeIt">{{cite web|last1=Lindley|first1=Thomas Ricks|title=Gonzales Come and Take It Cannon|url=https://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/qvg01|website=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}</ref> [[John Henry Moore (Texas)|John Henry Moore]] led 150 Texian militia on October 2 in successfully repelling the Mexican troops. A "Come and Take It" flag was later fashioned by the women of Gonzales.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hardin|first1=Stephen L.|title=Battle of Gonzales|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/qeg03|website=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}</ref> The cannon was moved to [[San Antonio|San Antonio de Béxar]] and became one of the artillery pieces used by the defenders of the Alamo.{{refn|group=FN| name=Gonzalescannon|While it is not certain what became of the cannon, Santa Anna ordered all brass and bronze artillery seized after the battle to be melted down.<ref>Davis (2004), p. 223.</ref>}}
The immediate result of the Texian victory at Gonzales was that two days later the number of volunteers had swelled to over 300, and they were determined to drive the Mexican army out of Texas.<ref>Davis (2004), pp. 142–145.</ref> Simultaneously, a [[Company (military unit)|company]] of volunteers under George M. Collinsworth captured the Presidio La Bahía from the Mexicans on October 9 at the [[Battle of Goliad]].<ref>Davis (2004), p. 147.</ref> The Mexican government's response to the unrest in Texas was an October 30 authorization of war.<ref name=todish124>Todish ''et al.'' (1998), p. 124.</ref> On the banks of the Nueces River {{convert|3|mi|km}} from San Patricio on November 4 during the [[Battle of Lipantitlán]], volunteers under [[Ira Westover]] captured the fort from Mexican troops.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Guthrie|first1=Keith|title=Battle of Lipantitlán|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/qfl03|website=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}</ref>
==Béxar: 1835 - 1836==
===Siege of Béxar and its aftermath: October 1835 - February 1836===
By October 9, Cos had taken over San Antonio de Béxar.<ref name=todish124/> Stephen F. Austin sent an advance scout troop of 90 men under [[James Bowie]] and [[James Fannin]] to observe the Mexican forces. While taking refuge at [[Mission Concepción]] on October 28, they repelled an attack by 275 Mexicans under [[Domingo Ugartechea]] during the [[Battle of Concepción|battle]].<ref>Davis (2004), pp. 157–159; {{cite web|last1=Barr|first1=Alwyn|title=Battle of Concepcion|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/qec02|website=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}</ref> Austin continued to send troops to Béxar. Bowie was ordered on November 26 to attack a Mexican supply train alleged to be carrying a payroll. The resulting skirmish became known as the [[Grass Fight]], after it was discovered that the only cargo was grass to feed the horses.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Barr|first1=Alwyn|title=Grass Fight|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/qfg01|website=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}</ref> When Austin was selected to join [[Branch T. Archer]] and [[William H. Wharton]] on a diplomatic mission to seek international recognition and support, Edward Burleson was named as commander.<ref>{{cite journal|title=New Orleans, Maritime Commerce, and the Texas War for Independence, 1836|first=James M.|last= Denham|journal=The Southwestern Historical Quarterly|volume= 97| issue = 3 |date=January 1994|pages=510–534|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|jstor=30241429|subscription=yes}}; {{cite web|title=The Siege of Béxar|url=https://www.tsl.texas.gov/treasures/republic/Béxar/Béxar.html|publisher=Texas Library and Archives Commission|accessdate=May 29, 2015}}</ref> On December 5, James C. Neill began distracting Cos by firing artillery directly at the Alamo, while [[Benjamin Milam]] and [[Frank W. Johnson]] led several hundred volunteers in a surprise attack. The fighting at the [[Siege of Béxar]] continued until December 9 when Cos sent word he wanted to surrender. Cos and his army were sent back to Mexico, but would later unite with Santa Anna's forces.<ref>Davis (2004), pp. 182–185.</ref>
Approximately 300 of the Texian garrison at Béxar departed on December 30 to join Frank W. Johnson and [[James Grant (Texas)|James Grant]] on the [[Matamoros Expedition]], in a planned attack to seize the port for its financial resources.<ref>Todish ''et al.'' (1998), p. 29, 125.</ref> Proponents of this campaign were hoping Mexican Federalists{{refn|group=FN| name=Federalist}} would oust Santa Anna and restore the 1824 constitution.<ref>Davis (2004), pp. 75, 186–187; {{cite web|last1=Roell|first1=Craig H.|title=Matamoros Expedition|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/qdm01|website=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}</ref> When Sesma crossed the Rio Grande, residents of the Gulf Coast began fleeing the area in January 1836.<ref name="Scrape"/> Santa Anna ordered General [[José de Urrea]] on February 16 to secure the Gulf Coast.<ref name="Ref-1">Todish ''et al.'' (1998), pp. 126–127.</ref> About {{convert|160|mi|km}} north of Matamoros at [[San Patricio, Texas|San Patricio]], Urrea's troops ambushed Johnson and members of the expedition on February 27 at the [[Battle of San Patricio]]. Sixteen Texians were killed, six escaped, and 21 were taken prisoner.<ref>Todish ''et al.'' (1998), p. 128; Jackson, Wheat (2005), p. 372.</ref> Urrea's troops then turned southwest by some {{convert|26|mi|km}} to Agua Dulce Creek and on March 2 attacked a group of the expedition led by Grant, killing all but 11, six of whom were taken prisoner. Five of the men escaped the [[Battle of Agua Dulce]] and joined Fannin who wanted to increase the defense force at Goliad.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bishop|first1=Curtis|title=Battle of Agua Dulce Creek|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/qfa01|website=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}; {{cite web|last1=Hartmann|first1=Clinton P.|title=James Walker Fannin Jr.|url=https://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/ffa02|website=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}</ref>
===Battle of the Alamo: February 23 – March 6, 1836=== {{Main|Battle of the Alamo}} Neill was promoted to lieutenant colonel during his participation in the Siege of Béxar,<ref name="Neill"/> and 10 days later Houston placed him in charge of the Texian garrison in the city.<ref>Todish ''et al.'' (1998), pp. 29, 125.</ref> In January residents had begun evacuating ahead of Santa Anna's approaching forces.<ref name="TxMonthly">{{cite magazine|last1=Reid|first1=Jan|title=The Runaway Scrape|magazine=Texas Monthly|date=May 1989|page=130|url=https://books.google.com/?id=Ri4EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA130&dq=san+patricio+%22runaway+scrape%22#v=onepage&q=san%20patricio%20%22runaway%20scrape%22&f=false|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}</ref> Neill pleaded with Houston for replenishment of troops, supplies and weaponry. The departure of Texians who joined the Matamoros Expedition had left Neill with only about 100 men. At that point Houston viewed Béxar as a military liability and did not want Santa Anna's advancing army gaining control of any remaining soldiers or artillery. He dispatched Bowie with instructions to remove the artillery, have the defenders abandon the [[Battle of the Alamo|Alamo mission]] and destroy it.{{refn|group=FN| name=Bowie|Historians disagree as to the clarity of Houston's orders. In a letter dated January 17, 1836, Houston's wording seems to leave the final decision to provisional Governor Henry Smith. "Colonel Bowie will leave here in a few hours for Bexar, with a detachment of from thirty to fifty men. I have ordered the fortifications in the town of Bexar to be demolished, and if you think well of it, I will remove all the cannon and other munitions of war to Gonzales and Copano, blow up the Alamo, and abandon the place, as it will be impossible to keep up the Station with volunteers." The fractious provisional government had impeached Smith on January 11.<ref>Todish ''et al.'' (1998), pp. 31, 139, 226; {{cite web|last1=Hardin|first1=Stephen L.|title=Battle of the Alamo|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/qea02|website=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}</ref>}} Upon his January 19 arrival<ref name=todish126/> and subsequent discussions with Neill, Bowie decided the mission was the right place to stop the Mexican army in its tracks. He stayed and began to help Neill prepare for the coming attack. Lieutenant Colonel [[William B. Travis]] arrived with reinforcements on February 3.<ref>{{cite web|last1=McDonald|first1=Archie P.|title=William Barret Travis|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/ftr03|website=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}</ref> When Neill was given leave to attend to family matters on February 11, Travis assumed command of the mission, and three days later he and Bowie agreed to a joint command.<ref>Todish ''et al.'' (1998), p.126; Moore (2004), p. 39.</ref> Santa Anna crossed the Rio Grande on February 16, and the Mexican army's assault on the Alamo began February 23.<ref name="Ref-1"/> Captain [[Juan Seguín]] left the mission on February 25, carrying a letter from Travis to Fannin at Goliad requesting more reinforcements.<ref>Todish ''et al.'' (1998), p. 43; Moore (2004), p. 28.</ref> Santa Anna extended an offer of amnesty to Tejanos inside the fortress; a non-combatant survivor, Enrique Esparza, said that most Tejanos left when Bowie advised them to take the offer.<ref>Poyo (1996), p. 53, 58 "Efficient in the Cause" (Stephen L. Harden); Lindley (2003), p. 94, 134.</ref> In response to Travis' [[To the People of Texas & All Americans in the World|February 24 letter To the People of Texas]], 32 militia volunteers formed the Gonzales Ranging Company of Mounted Volunteers and arrived at the Alamo on February 29.{{refn|group=FN| name=Militia}}
{{quote|If you execute your enemies, it saves you the trouble of having to forgive them.|General Antonio López de Santa Anna, February 1836<ref>Todish ''et al.'' (1998), p. 142.</ref>}}
==Flight: March – April 1836==
===Houston begins forming his army===
As the closest settlement to San Antonio de Béxar, Gonzales was the rallying point for volunteers who responded to both the Travis letter from the Alamo and Houston's recruitment pleas. Recently formed groups came from Austin and Washington counties and from the Colorado River area.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 22–24, 51.</ref> Volunteers from [[Brazoria County, Texas|Brazoria]], [[Fort Bend County, Texas|Fort Bend]] and [[Matagorda County, Texas|Matagorda]] counties organized after arriving in Gonzales.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 49, 51.</ref> The Kentucky Rifle company under [[Newport, Kentucky]] business man [[Sidney Sherman]] had been aided by funding from [[Cincinnati]], [[Ohio]] residents.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Beazley|first1=Julia|title=Sidney Sherman|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fsh27|website=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}; Moore (2004), pp. 24–27, 51.</ref>
Alamo commandant Neill was in Gonzales purchasing supplies and recruiting reinforcements on March 6. When Seguin learned en route that Fannin would be unable to reach the Alamo in time,<ref>Moore (2004), p. 28.</ref> he immediately began mustering an all-[[Tejano]] company of scouts.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 28–29, 51.</ref> His men combined with Lieutenant William Smith's and volunteered to accompany Neill's recruits. They encountered the Mexican army {{convert|18|mi|km}} from the Alamo on March 7, and Neill's men turned back while the Seguin-Smith scouts moved forward.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 39–40.</ref> As the scouts neared the Alamo, they met only silence.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 39–43, 46, 51.</ref> Andrew Barcena and Anselmo Bergara from Seguin's other detachment inside the Alamo showed up in Gonzales on March 11, telling of their escape and delivering news of the slaughter. Their stories were discounted; Houston, who had arrived that same day, denounced them as Mexican spies.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 45–46, 163, 171.</ref>
Smith and Seguin confirmed the fate of the mission upon their return. Houston dispatched orders to Fannin to abandon Goliad, blow up the [[Presidio La Bahía]] fortress, and retreat to [[Victoria, Texas|Victoria]],<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 46–47.</ref> but Fannin delayed acting on those orders. Believing the approach of Urrea's troops brought a greater urgency to local civilians, he sent 29 men under Captain Amon B. King to help evacuate nearby [[Refugio, Texas|Refugio]].<ref>Moore (2004), p. 47, 67.</ref>
Houston promptly began organizing the troops at Gonzales into the First Regiment under Burleson who had arrived as part of the [[Bastrop, Texas|Mina]] volunteers.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 19–22, 51.</ref> A second regiment would later be formed when the army grew large enough.<ref>Moore (2004), p. 48.</ref> As others began to arrive, individual volunteers not already in another company were put under Captain William Hestor Patton.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 51–52.</ref> Houston had 374 volunteers and their commanders in Gonzales on March 12.<ref>Moore (2004), p. 51.</ref>
Santa Anna sent [[Susanna Dickinson]] with her infant daughter Angelina, Travis' slave Joe, and Mexican Colonel [[Juan Almonte]]'s cook Ben to Gonzales, with dispatches written in English by Almonte to spread the news of the fall of the Alamo.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 37–38.</ref> Scouts [[Deaf Smith]], [[Henry Karnes]] and Robert Eden Handy encountered the survivors {{convert|20|mi|km}} outside of Gonzales on March 13. When Karnes returned with the news, almost immediately 25 volunteers deserted. Wailing filled the air when Dickinson and the others reached the town with their first-hand accounts.<ref name="Scrape">{{cite web|last1=Covington|first1=Carolyn Callaway|title=Runaway Scrape|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/pfr01|website=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}; Moore (2004), pp. 55–56.</ref>
{{quote|There was not a soul left among the citizens of Gonzales who had not lost a father, husband, brother or son ... That terrible massacre had, for a time, struck terror into every heart.|John Milton Swisher, private in William W. Hill's volunteers.<ref>Moore (2004), p. 56.</ref>}} [[File:Braches House and Sam Houston Oak.JPG|thumb|The Sam Houston Oak{{refn|group=FN| name=Oak}} where the Provisional Army of Texas rested after the burning of Gonzales|alt=The Sam Houston Oak where the Provisional Army of Texas rested after the burning of Gonzales]]
Although civilian evacuations had begun in January for the Gulf Coast and San Antonio de Béxar, the Texian military was either on the offensive or standing firm until the smaller Gulf Coast skirmishes happened in February. Houston was now facing a choice of whether to retreat to a safe place to train his new army, or to meet the enemy head-on immediately.<ref name=hm9>Hardin, McBride (2001), p. 9.</ref> He was wary of trying to defend a fixed position – the debacle at the Alamo had shown that the new Texian government was unable to provide sufficient provisions or reinforcements.<ref>Hardin (1994), p. 179.</ref>
===The burning of Gonzales===
Houston called for a Council of War. The officers voted that the families should be ordered to leave, and the troops would cover the retreat. By midnight, less than an hour after Dickinson had arrived, the combined army and civilian population began a frantic move eastward,<ref name=hm9/> leaving behind everything they could not immediately grab and transport. Much of the provisions and artillery were left behind, including two 24-pounder cannons.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 57–60; Hardin, McBride (2001), p. 9.</ref> Houston ordered [[Salvador Flores]] along with a company of Juan Seguin's men to form the rear guard to protect the fleeing families. Couriers were sent to other towns in Texas to warn that the Mexican army was advancing.<ref>Moore (2004), p. 60.</ref>
The retreat took place so quickly that many of the Texian scouts did not fully comprehend it until after the town was evacuated.<ref>Moore (2004), p. 58.</ref> Houston ordered Karnes to burn the town and everything in it so nothing would remain to benefit the Mexican troops. By dawn, the entire town was in ashes or flames.<ref>Moore (2004), p. 59.</ref>
Volunteers from San Felipe de Austin who had been organized under Captain John Bird on March 5 to reinforce the men at the Alamo<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 61–63.</ref> had been en route to San Antonio de Béxar on March 13 when approximately {{convert|10|mi|km}} east of Gonzales they encountered fleeing citizens and a courier from Sam Houston. Told of the Alamo's fall, Bird's men offered assistance to the fleeing citizens and joined Houston's army at Bartholomew D. McClure's plantation on the evening of March 14.{{refn|group=FN| name=Oak|A historical plaque denotes the Sam Houston Oak in front of the [[Braches House]], which itself is on the [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Gonzales County, Texas|NRHP]].<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 63–67; {{cite web|title=Sam Houston Oak|url=http://atlas.thc.state.tx.us/Details/5177004503|website=Recorded Texas Historic Landmarks|publisher=Texas Historical Commission|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}; {{cite web|title=Braches House|url=http://atlas.thc.state.tx.us/Details/2071000936|website=NRHP Texas landmarks|publisher=Texas Historical Commission|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}</ref>}}
At Washington-on-the-Brazos, the delegates to the convention learned of the Alamo's fall on March 13.<ref>Davis (2004), p. 241.</ref> The Republic's new ''ad interim'' government was sworn in on March 17, with a department overseeing military spy operations, and adjourned the same day.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 77–79.</ref> The government then fled to Groce's Landing where they stayed for several days before moving on to Harrisburg on March 21 where they established temporary headquarters in the home of widow Jane Birdsall Harris.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Muir|first1=Andrew Forest|title=Jane Birdsall Harris|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fha83|website=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}; Todish ''et al.'' (1998), p. 103; Moore (2004), p. 139.</ref>
King's men at Refugio had taken refuge in Mission Nuestra Señora de la Rosario when they were subsequently attacked by Urrea's forces. Fannin sent 120 reinforcements under [[William Ward (Texas)|William Ward]], but the March 14 [[Battle of Refugio]] cost 15 Texian lives.<ref>Todish ''et al.'' (1998), p. 129.</ref> Ward's men escaped, but King's men were captured and executed on March 16.<ref>Moore (2004), p. 68</ref>
===Colorado River crossings===
====Burnam's==== Upon learning of the flight, Santa Anna sent General Joaquín Ramírez y Sesma with 700 men to pursue Houston, and 600 men under General Eugenio Tolsa as reinforcements. Finding only burned remains at Gonzales, Sesma marched his army toward the [[Colorado River (Texas)|Colorado River]].<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 71–72.</ref>
The Texian army camped March 15–18 on the [[Lavaca River]] property of Williamson Daniels<ref>Moore (2004), p. 66; {{cite web|title=Site of the Camp of the Texas Army|url=http://atlas.thc.state.tx.us/Details/5285004924|website=Recorded Texas Historic Landmarks|publisher=Texas Historical Commission|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}</ref> where they were joined by combined forces under Joe Bennett and Captain Peyton R. Splane.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 69–73.</ref> Fleeing civilians accompanied Houston's army turning north at the [[Navidad River]] as they crossed to the east side of the Colorado River at Burnam's Crossing.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 75–76, 83; {{cite web|title=Route of the Texas Army|url=http://atlas.thc.state.tx.us/Details/5285004375|website=Recorded Texas Historic Landmarks|publisher=Texas Historical Commission|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}</ref> The ferry and trading post, as well as the family home of Jesse Burnam, were all burned at Houston's orders on March 17 to prevent Santa Anna's army from making the same crossing.{{refn|group=FN| name=Burnam|The ferry and trading post had been built by Jesse Burnam in 1824, and had survived numerous attacks from [[Karankawa|Karankawa indians]]. Burnam later claimed Houston destroyed his property because of personal issues between the two, not because of any threat from the Mexican army.<ref>Watts (2008), p. 18; Awbrey, Dooley (2005), p. 537; Haley (2002). pp. 126–127; {{cite web|title=Burnam's Ferry|url=http://atlas.thc.state.tx.us/Details/5089000575|publisher=Texas Historical Commission|accessdate=December 18, 2014}}; {{cite web|last1=Largent, Jr.|first1=F. B.|title=Burnam's Ferry|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/rtb01|website=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 19, 2014}}; {{cite web|last1=Largent, Jr.|first1=F. B.|title=Jesse Burnam|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fbu45|website=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 19, 2014}}</ref>}}
====Beason's and DeWees==== [[File:Campaigns of the Texas Revolution.jpg|thumb|upright=1.5|Campaigns of the Texas Revolution|alt=Campaigns of the Texas Revolution]]
Beason's Crossing was located where [[Columbus, Texas|Columbus]] is today.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Allon Hinton|first1=Don Allon|title=Columbus, Texas|url=https://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/hgc12|website=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=August 8, 2015}}</ref> DeWees Crossing was {{convert|7|mi|km|}} north of Beason's. From March 19 through March 26, Houston split his forces between the two crossings.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 90, 94–95.</ref> Additional Texian volunteer companies began arriving at both crossings, including three companies of [[Texas Ranger Division|Texas Rangers]], the Liberty County Volunteers and the Nacogdoches Volunteers.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 90, 97, 99–103, 118–120, 126.</ref>
Sesma's [[battalion]] of approximately 725 men and artillery camped on the opposite side of the Colorado, at a distance halfway between the two Texian camps.<ref name=Moore9495>Moore (2004), pp. 94, 95.</ref> To prevent Sesma's troops from using the William DeWees log cabin, Sherman ordered it burned.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 98–99.</ref> Three Mexican scouts from Sesma's army were captured by Sherman's men, and although Sherman argued for an attack on Sesma's troops, Houston was not ready.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 107, 111.</ref>
Fannin had begun evacuating Presidio La Bahía on March 19. The estimated 320 troops were low on food and water, and the breakdown of a wagon allowed Urrea's men to overtake them at [[Battle of Coleto|Coleto Creek]], ending in Fannin's surrender on March 20.<ref name="Coleto">{{cite web|last1=Roell|first1=Craig H.|title=Battle of Coleto|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/qec01|website=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}; Todish ''et al.'' (1998), p.130.</ref> [[Peter Kerr (Texas settler)|Peter Kerr]], who had served with Fannin and claimed to have been held prisoner, arrived at DeWees on March 25. Houston announced Fannin's surrender,<ref name=moore147>Moore (2004), p. 147.</ref> but would later claim to have uncovered evidence that Kerr was a spy for the Mexicans.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 114, 144, 171.</ref>
The Texian army was a force of 810 volunteers and staff at this point,<ref>Moore (2004), p. 100</ref> but few had any military training and experience. Faced with past desertions, discipline flaws, and individual indecisiveness of volunteers in training, Houston knew they were not yet ready to engage the Mexican army. Compounding the situation were the civilian refugees dependent upon the army for their protection.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 126–130.</ref> The news of Fannin's capture, combined with his doubts about the readiness of the Texian army, led Houston to order a retreat on March 26.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 114–118.</ref> Some of the troops viewed the decision as cowardice with Sesma sitting just on the other side of the Colorado, and several hundred men deserted.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 117–118.</ref>
{{quote|... the only army in Texas is now present ... There are but few of us, and if we are beaten, the fate of Texas is sealed. The salvation of the country depends upon the first battle had with the enemy. For this reason, I intend to retreat, if I am obliged to go even to the banks of the Sabine.|Sam Houston<ref>Haley (2002), p. 129.</ref>}}
===Brazos River training camp===
==== Groce's Landing ==== Texian survivors of the Battle of Coleto Creek believed their surrender agreement with Urrea would, at worst, mean their deportation. Santa Anna, however, adhered to the 1835 [[Tornel Decree]] that stated the insurrection was an act of piracy fomented by the United States, and ordered their executions.{{refn|group=FN| name=Goliad|Historians Jack Jackson and John Wheat in their research of Mexican government records believe that although the wording of the December 30, 1835 Tornel Decree specified "foreigners", the document was a mere formality to green-light Santa Anna's broader plan of dealing with opposition both foreign and domestic. In a letter to General Joaquín Ramírez y Sesma on February 29, 1836, Santa Anna wrote "in this war there are no prisoners". At the [[Battle of the Alamo]] prior to the final siege, he offered a three-day amnesty to allow Tejanos inside the mission to leave unharmed. At other skirmishes in the war, there is no indication either he or his generals made that distinction. Jackson and White stated, "When he learned that Urrea had taken several hundred prisoners near Goliad, Santa Anna expressed his amazement that they had not been treated as pirates and swiftly executed as Tornel's decree specified. He sent more letters until the tragic deed was done." <ref>Jackson, Wheat (2005), pp. 374, 377, 386–387; Poyo (1996), pp. 53, 58 "Efficient in the Cause" (Stephen L. Harden); Lindley (2003), pp. 94, 134; Todish et al. (1998), pp. 137–138.</ref>}} Although he personally disagreed with the need to do so, Urrea carried out his commander's orders on March 27.<ref>Haley (2002), p. 130.</ref> Of the estimated 370 Texians being held, a few managed to escape the massacre. The remainder were shot, stabbed with bayonets and lances and clubbed with gun butts. Fannin was shot through the face and his gold watch stolen. The dead were cremated on a [[pyre]].<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 128–133.</ref>
It would be a week before word of the [[Goliad massacre]] reached Sam Houston. The retreating Texian army stopped at San Felipe de Austin<ref>Moore (2004), p. 128.</ref> on March 28–29 to stock up on food and supplies.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 135–136.</ref> Houston's plan to move the army north to Groce's Landing on the Brazos River was met with resistance from captains Wyly Martin and Moseley Baker, whose units balked at further retreat. Houston reassigned Martin {{convert|25|mi|km}} south to protect the Morton Ferry crossing at Fort Bend, and Baker was ordered to guard the river crossing at San Felipe de Austin.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 136–137.</ref>
News of approaching Mexican troops and Houston's retreat caused panic among the population in the counties of Washington, [[Sabine County, Texas|Sabine]], [[Shelby County, Texas|Shelby]] and [[San Augustine County, Texas|San Augustine]]. Amid the confusion of fleeing residents of those counties, two volunteer groups under captains William Kimbro and Benjamin Bryant arrived to join Houston on March 29. Kimbro was ordered to San Felipe de Austin to reinforce Baker's troops, while Bryant's men remained with the main army.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 145–146, 163–164.</ref>
After an erroneous scouting report of approaching Mexican troops, Baker burned San Felipe de Austin to the ground on March 30.<ref name="SF"/> When Baker claimed Houston had given him an order to do so, Houston denied it.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 140–141.</ref> Houston's account was that the residents burned their own property to keep it out of the hands of the Mexican army.<ref name=moore147/> San Felipe de Austin's residents did as those before them in escaping the Mexican army, and fled to the east.<ref name="SF">{{cite web|last1=Christopher|first1=Charles|title=San Felipe de Austin de Austin, Tx|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/hls10|website=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}</ref>
During a two-week period beginning March 31, the Texian army camped on the west side of the [[Brazos River]] in [[Austin County, Texas|Austin County]], near Groce's Landing (also known as Groce's Ferry).<ref>{{cite web|last1=Berlet|first1=Sarah Groce|title=Groce's Ferry|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/rtg02|website=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}</ref> As Houston led his army north towards the landing, the unrelenting rainy weather swelled the Brazos and threatened flooding.<ref>Moore (2004), p. 162.</ref> Groce's was transformed into a training camp for the troops.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 151–152.</ref> Major Edwin Morehouse arrived with a New York battalion of recruits who were immediately assigned to assist Wyly Martin at Fort Bend.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Cutrer|first1=Thomas W.|title=Edwin Morehouse|website=Handbook of Texas Online|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fmo42 |publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}; Moore (2004), p. 157.</ref> Civilian men who were fleeing the Mexicans enlisted at Groce's,<ref>Moore (2004), pp.147–148.</ref> and displaced civilian women in the camp helped the army's efforts by sewing shirts for the soldiers.<ref name=moore149>Moore (2004), p. 149.</ref>
Samuel G. Hardaway, a survivor of Major William Ward's group who had escaped the Battle of Refugio and re-joined Fannin at the Battle of Coleto, also managed to escape the Goliad massacre. As he fled Goliad, he was eventually joined by three other survivors, Joseph Andrews, James P. Trezevant and M. K. Moses. Spies for the Texian army discovered the four men and took them to Baker's camp near San Felipe de Austin on April 2.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 157–158.</ref> Several other survivors of the Goliad massacre were found on April 10 by Texian spies. Survivors Daniel Murphy, Thomas Kemp, Charles Shain, David Jones, William Brenan and Nat Hazen were taken to Houston at Groce's Landing where they enlisted to fight with Houston's army.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 194–195.</ref>
Houston learned of the Goliad massacre on April 3. Unaware that Secretary of War Rusk was already en route to Groce's with orders from President Burnet to halt the army's retreat and engage the enemy, he relayed the Goliad news by letter to Rusk.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Benham|first1=Priscilla Myers|title=Thomas Jefferson Rusk|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fru16|website=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}; Moore (2004), pp. 165, 167,169.</ref>
{{quote|The enemy are laughing you to scorn. You must fight them. You must retreat no further. The country expects you to fight. The salvation of the country depends on your doing so.|David G. Burnet, ''ad interim'' president of the Republic of Texas<ref>Moore (2004), p. 189.</ref>}}
Empowered to remove Houston from command and take over the army himself, Rusk instead assessed Houston's plan of action as correct, after witnessing the training at Groce's. Rusk and Houston formed the Second Regiment on April 8 to serve under Sherman, with Burleson retaining command of the First Regiment.{{refn|group=FN|name=Thomas|Attorney General David Thomas was named as acting Secretary of War when Rusk joined the army.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kemp|first1=L. W.|title=David Thomas|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fth07|website=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}; Moore (2004), pp. 183–185.</ref>}}
====''Yellowstone'' steamboat==== The steamboat ''[[Yellowstone (steamboat)|Yellowstone]]''<ref name=moore149/> under the command of Captain John Eautaw Ross was impressed into service for the Provisional Army of Texas on April 2, and initially ferried patients across the Brazos River when Dr. James Aeneas Phelps established a field hospital at Bernardo Plantation.<ref>Moore (2004), p. 156.</ref> Three days later, Santa Anna joined with Sesma's troops,<ref>Moore (2004), p. 176.</ref> and had them build flatboats to cross the Brazos as the Mexicans sought to overtake and defeat the Texians.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 179,181.</ref> Wyly Martin reported on April 8 that Mexican forces had divided and were headed both east to Nacogdoches and southeast to Matagorda.<ref>Moore (2004), p. 182.</ref> Houston reinforced Baker's post at San Felipe de Austin on April 9,<ref>Moore (2004), p. 186.</ref> as Santa Anna continued moving southeast on April 10.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 186–187.</ref>
The Texian army was transported by the ''Yellowstone'' over to the east side of the Brazos on April 12, where they set up camp at the Bernardo Plantation.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 198–200.</ref> After walking {{convert|50|mi|km}} from Harrisburg, future president of the Republic [[Mirabeau B. Lamar]] arrived at Bernardo to enlist as a private in Houston's army and suggested using the steamer for guerilla warfare.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 203–204; {{cite web|last1=Gambrell|first1=Herbert|title=Mirabeau Buonaparte Lamar|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fla15|website=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}</ref>
{{quote|Had it not been for its service, the enemy could never have been overtaken until they had reached the Sabine ... use of the boat enabled me to cross the Brazos and save Texas.|Sam Houston on the ''Yellowstone's'' contributions<ref>Greene (1998), pp. 19–21.</ref>}}
With Baker guarding the crossing at San Felipe de Austin, and Martin guarding the Morton Ferry crossing<ref>{{cite web|title=John V. Morton|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fmo69|website=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}</ref> at Ford Bend, Santa Anna opted on April 12 to cross the Brazos halfway between at Thompson's Ferry,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hardin|first1=Stephen F.|title=Thompson's Ferry|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/rtt01|website=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}</ref> with Sesma's men and artillery crossing over the next day.<ref name=moore206207>Moore (2004), pp. 206–207.</ref> The Mexican army attacked the steamer numerous times in an attempt to capture it, but Ross successfully used cotton bales to protect the steamer and its cargo, and was able to keep the ''Yellowstone'' away from Mexican control.<ref name=moore206207/> Houston released the steamboat from service on April 14, and it continued to Galveston.<ref>Moore (2004), p. 212.</ref>
===Burning of Harrisburg and the crucial crossroads===
The ''ad interim'' government departed Harrisburg on the steamboat ''Cayuga'' for [[Morgan's Point, Texas|New Washington]] ahead of Santa Anna's April 15 arrival,<ref>Moore (2004), p. 207.</ref> thwarting his plans to eliminate the entire government of the Republic of Texas.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 195–197, 207.</ref> Three printers still at work on the ''[[Telegraph and Texas Register]]'' told the Mexican army that everyone in the government had already left, and Santa Anna responded by having the printers arrested and the printing presses tossed into [[Buffalo Bayou]].<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 219–220; Fischer (1976), p. 88.</ref> After days of looting and seeking out information about the government, Santa Anna ordered the town burned on April 18.<ref>Davis (2004), pp. 264–165.</ref> He later tried to place the blame for the destruction on Houston.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 218–219, 232–233; Todish ''et al.'' (1998), p.130.</ref>
[[File:Twin Sisters, San Jacinto.jpg|thumb|Replicas of the Twin Sisters cannons at [[San Jacinto Battleground State Historic Site]]|alt=Replicas of the Twin Sisters cannons at San Jacinto Battleground State Historic Site]] Before the Texian army left Bernardo Plantation, they welcomed the arrival of two cannons cast in November 1835 by Greenwood and Webb in [[Cincinnati, Ohio]], funded entirely by the people of that city as a donation to the Texas Revolution. The idea had arisen as a suggestion from Robert F. Lytle, one of the businessmen who helped fund Sherman's Kentucky Riflemen.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 15, 152–153.</ref> Arriving in [[New Orleans]] after a lengthy trip from Ohio on the [[Mississippi River]], the cannons were transported to the [[Gulf Coast of Texas|Gulf Coast]] aboard the ''Pennsylvania'' schooner. The cannons were nicknamed the "Twin Sisters", perhaps in honor of the twins Elizabeth and Eleanor Rice traveling aboard the ''Pennsylvania'', who were to present the cannons upon their arrival at Galveston in April 1836.<ref name="Twins">{{cite web|last1=Hunt|first1=Jeffrey William|title=Twin Sisters|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/qvt01|website=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}</ref><ref>Moore (2004), p. 185; Haley (2002), p. 137.</ref> At Galveston, Leander Smith had the responsibility of transporting the cannons from Harrisburg to Bernardo Plantation in Waller County. Along the way, Smith recruited 35 men into the army.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 171–173, 201–202.</ref> Lieutenant Colonel James Neill was put in charge of the cannons once they arrived in camp.<ref name=moore212213>Moore (2004), pp. 212–213.</ref>
Martin and Baker abandoned the river crossings on April 14 and re-joined Houston's army which had marched from Bernardo to the Charles Donoho Plantation near present-day [[Hempstead, Texas|Hempstead]] in Waller County.<ref>Moore (2004), p. 214; {{cite web|title=Charles Donoho Plantation|website=Recorded Texas Historic Landmarks|publisher=Texas Historical Commission|accessdate=December 1, 2014|url=http://atlas.thc.state.tx.us/Details/5507013721}}</ref> As news spread of the Mexican army's movements, residents of Nacogdoches and [[San Augustine, Texas|San Augustine]] began to flee east towards the Sabine River. After refusals to continue with the army, Martin was ordered by Houston to accompany displaced families on their flight eastward. Hundreds of soldiers left the army to help their families. The main army parted from the refugees at this point, and acting Secretary of War David Thomas{{refn|group=FN|name=Thomas}} advised Houston to move southward to secure Galveston Bay.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 215–217.</ref> Houston, however, was getting conflicting advice from the cabinet members. President Burnet had sent Secretary of State Carson to Louisiana in hopes of getting the United States army and individual state militias involved in the Texas fight for independence. While he attempted to secure such involvement, Carson sent a dispatch to Houston on April 14 advising him to retreat all the way to the Louisiana-Texas border on the Sabine River, and bide his time before engaging the Mexican army.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 211–212.</ref>
The Texian army camped west of present-day [[Tomball, Texas|Tomball]] on April 15, at Sam McCarley's homestead.<ref>{{cite web|title=Samuel McCarley Homesite|url=http://atlas.thc.state.tx.us/Details/5201010726|website=Recorded Texas Historic Landmarks|publisher=Texas Historical Commission|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}; Moore (2004), pp. 220–221.</ref> They departed the next morning<ref>Moore (2004), p. 222.</ref> and {{convert|3|mi|km}} east reached a crucial crossroads.{{refn|group=FN|name=Fork|In Texas history and in historical works on Sam Houston, this is referred to as "the fork in the road" where Houston stopped retreating and instead actively pursued Santa Anna. The site is now designated as a Recorded Texas Historic Landmark and located in the present day Harris County city of Tomball.<ref>Moore (2004), p. 225; {{cite web|title=Abraham Roberts Homesite|url=http://atlas.thc.state.tx.us/Details/5201010747|website=Recorded Texas Historic Landmarks|publisher=Texas Historical Commission|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}</ref>}} One road led east to Nacogdoches and eventually the Sabine River and Louisiana, while the other road led southeast to Harrisburg. The army was concerned that Houston would continue the eastward retreat. Although Houston discussed his decision with no one, he led the army down the southeast road. Rusk ordered that a small group of volunteers be split from the army to secure Robbins's Ferry on the Trinity River.<ref>{{cite web|title=Robbins's Ferry|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/rtr01|website=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}; Moore (2004), pp. 226–227.</ref> Houston's troops stopped overnight on April 16 at the home of Matthew Burnet, and the next morning continued marching towards Harrisburg, {{convert|25|mi|km}} southeast.<ref>{{cite web|title=Matthew Burnett Homesite|url=http://atlas.thc.state.tx.us/Details/5201010623|website=Recorded Texas Historic Landmarks|publisher=Texas Historical Commission|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}; Moore (2004), p. 229.</ref>
With the refugee families being accorded a military escort eastward and Houston marching southeast, the retreat of the Provisional Army of Texas was over. On the march which would lead to San Jacinto, moving the heavy artillery across rain-soaked terrain slowed down the army's progress.<ref name=moore212213/> The army had previously been assisted in moving the Twin Sisters with oxen borrowed from refugee Pamela Martin when she believed the army was fleeing towards Nacogdoches. When she learned the army was headed towards Harrisburg and a confrontation with the Mexican army, she reclaimed her oxen.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 227–228.</ref> The Texian army had expanded to twenty-six companies by the time they reached Harrisburg on April 18 and saw the destruction Santa Anna had left behind.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 233–235, 243.</ref>
===New Washington===
On orders of Santa Anna after the burning of Harrisburg, Almonte went in pursuit of the ''ad interim'' government at New Washington. During their flight the Republic officials switched from steamer to ferry to skiff. On the final leg of the trip, Almonte finally had them in his sights, but refused to fire after he saw Mrs. Burnet and her children on the skiff.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 230–232.</ref> In addition to letting the government get away one more time, Almonte's spies had misread Houston's troop movements and Santa Anna was told that the Texian army was still retreating eastward, this time through [[Lynchburg, Texas|Lynchburg]].<ref>Moore (2004), p. 230; {{cite web|title=Lynchburg Town Ferry|url=http://atlas.thc.state.tx.us/Details/5507013677|website=Recorded Texas Historical Landmarks|publisher=Texas Historical Commission|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}</ref>
New Washington was looted and burned on April 20 by Mexican troops,<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 235–237.</ref> and as many as 5,000 civilians fled, either by boat or across land. Those attempting to cross the [[San Jacinto River (Texas)|San Jacinto River]] were bottlenecked for three days, and the vicinity around the crossing transformed into a refugee camp. Burnet ordered government assistance all across Texas for fleeing families.<ref name=Downs>{{cite journal|last1=Downs|first1=Fane|title="Tryels and Trubbles":Women in Early Nineteenth-Century Texas|journal=Southwestern Historical Quarterly|date=1986–1987|volume=90|pages=50–55|url=http://texashistory.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metapth117152/m1/61/|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|location=Denton, TX}}</ref>
==Aftermath==
{{Main||Battle of San Jacinto}}
In a troop movement that took all night on a makeshift raft, the Texian army crossed Buffalo Bayou at Lynchburg April 19 with 930 soldiers, leaving behind 255 others as guards or for reasons of illness.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 242, 295–296; {{cite web|title=Sam Houston Crossed Buffalo Bayou|url=http://atlas.thc.state.tx.us/Details/5201010810|website=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}; Moore (2004), p. 251.</ref> The idea had been floated of leaving the Twin Sisters behind as protection, but Neill was adamant that the cannons be taken into the battle.<ref>Moore (2004), p. 246.</ref> In an April 20 skirmish the day before the main battle Neill was severely wounded,<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 264, 267.</ref> and [[George Washington Hockley|George Hockley]] took command of the heavy artillery.<ref>Moore (2004), p. 295.</ref> Estimates of the Mexican army troop strength on the day of the main battle range from 1,250 to 1,500.<ref>Moore (2004), p. 298; Todish ''et al.'' (1998), p. 131.</ref>
The Texians attacked in the afternoon of April 21 while Santa Anna was still under the misconception that Houston was actually retreating.<ref name=moore230>Moore (2004), p. 230.</ref> He had allowed his army time to relax and feed their horses, while he took a nap.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 328–329.</ref> When he was awakened by the attack, he immediately fled on horseback, but was later captured when Sergeant [[James Austin Sylvester]] found him hiding in the grass.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 337,353,377.</ref> Houston's own account was that the battle lasted "about eighteen minutes",<ref name=moore230/> before apprehending prisoners and confiscating armaments.<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 344–345.</ref> When the Twin Sisters went up against the Mexican army's Golden Standard cannon, they performed so well that Hockley's unit was able to capture the Mexican cannon.{{refn|group=FN| name=Cannon|The final fate of the Twin Sisters cannons is unknown. After the Battle of San Jacinto, the cannons were sent to Austin, Texas, to be used for ceremonial purposes. When the cannons were discovered to be in New Orleans, Sam Houston petitioned for their return to Texas at the onset of the Civil War. Their last known whereabouts was in 1863 at the [[Battle of Galveston]]. Replicas are on display at the San Jacinto Battleground State Historic Site.<ref>{{cite web|title=San Jacinto and the Mystery of the Twin Sisters Cannons|url=http://www.cemetery.state.tx.us/news.asp?newsid=9262|website=Texas State Cemetery|publisher=State of Texas|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}; Moore (2004), pp. 333–336.</ref>}}
The ''Yellowstone'' saw war service for the Republic one more time on May 7, when it transported Houston and his prisoner Santa Anna, along with the government Santa Anna tried to extinguish, to [[Galveston Island]].{{refn|group=FN| name=Yellowstone|Houston's agreement when he impressed the ''Yellowstone'' steamboat April 2 through April 14, was for Ross and the 17-man crew to receive at least 1/3 of a [[League (unit)|league]] of land (more for officers) as payment. The crew was not obligated to fight. When Stephen F. Austin died in December 1836, the ''Yellowstone'' transported his body to Brazoria County for burial. Nothing is known about the steamer after 1837.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Burkhalter|first1=Lois Wood|title=Yellow Stone|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/ety01|website=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}; Greene (1998), pp. 19–21.</ref>}} From there, the government and Santa Anna traveled to [[Velasco, Texas|Velasco]] for the signing of the [[Treaties of Velasco|treaties]].<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 375–386,405–407.</ref> Houston had suffered a serious wound during the battle,<ref>Moore (2004), pp. 338–339.</ref> and on May 28 boarded the schooner ''Flora'' for medical treatment in New Orleans.<ref>Moore (2004), p. 407.</ref>
Not until news of the victory at San Jacinto spread did the refugees return to their homesteads and businesses, or whatever was left after the destruction caused by both armies.<ref name="Scrape"/> Throughout Texas, possessions had been abandoned and later looted. Businesses, homes and farms were wiped out by the devastation of war. Often there was nothing left to go back to, but those who went home began to pick up their lives and move forward. San Felipe de Austin never really recovered from its total destruction. The few people who returned there moved elsewhere, sooner or later. Secretary of War Rusk would later commend the women of Texas who held their families together during the flight, while their men volunteered to fight: "The men of Texas deserve much credit, but more was due the women. Armed men facing a foe could not but be brave; but the women, with their little children around them, without means of defense or power to resist, faced danger and death with unflinching courage."<ref name=Downs/>
